description: Dive into "Castles of Enchantment in Rhodes Town" — a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Castles of Enchantment in Rhodes Town

places.generalDescription: Perched on a hill overlooking the Aegean Sea, Kritinia Castle, also known as Kastello to locals, is a historic Venetian/Byzantine castle dating back to 1472. Although now in ruins, the castle still showcases its former grandeur. Visitors can reach the site by taking a bus to Kritinia and walking or driving up the dirt track.

sources.snippet: Kritinia Castle, or Kastellos as the locals call it, is a type of Venetian castle that was constructed on a hill during the 16th century. It is built approximately 131 meters on top of a hill next to the village of Kritinia. The castle has long been considered a true gem of the village because it provides a panoramic view of the Aegean Sea, Chalki island, as well as the islets of Alimia, Makri, Strogyli, and more.
sources.shortName: Kritinia Castle / Castle of Kritinia - Rhodes Castles

sources.snippet: Kritinia Castle is located a 15-minute drive south of Kamiros, and if you rent a car I suggest you visit these two places on the same day. The distance between Kritinia Castle and Rhodes town is a 1-hour drive (46 km/28.5 miles). The imposing Kritinia Castle sits 130 meters above the village of Kritinia and close to the small Kamiros Skala harbour.
sources.shortName: 20 best things to do in Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Kritinia Castle stands 250m above the Aegean, one topless tower protruding precariously over the sea. The Knights built it just in time to help repel the 160-ship Ottoman invasion that arrived here in 1480 — an event that proved to be a bloody dress rehearsal for 1522.
sources.shortName: Rhodes: Castles, myths and sparkling azure bays

sources.snippet: I did this day trip which took us to Kritinia Castle, a Venetian castle ruin with incredible views across the sea. We also did a wine and honey tasting just outside the town of Embonas. Rhodes is known for its dry white wine and sweet wines.
sources.shortName: The Best Things To do in Rhodes, Greece: A Rhodes Itinerary

places.name: Kritinia Castle

reviews.text: Rather remote, but beautiful little ruin of a castle that must have been very impressive in the past. From the top of the ruin you have an impressive view into the bay and the small islands in the vicinity. On a clear day you can see the coastline of Turkey in the distance. In the public section there is no roof structure left, so in the very unlikely event of rainfall you would not have any meaningful cover. Great that this precious spot is free of charge.
Ruins of a castle with a nice view. Great spot for sunset. The entrance was free. It's a pity that it is not maintained

While driving around the island, we noticed signs pointing to the castle ruins and decided to make a spontaneous detour. The road leading up to the site is mostly tarmac and fairly accessible, with just a few short but steep sections near the top. Our small rental car managed it with no issues.

There's a free car park right by the castle that can hold around 15 cars, which was a nice bonus. Entry to the ruins is also free, accessed via a set of built steps. Just a note – not suitable for a wheelchair access, unfortunately.

Once you reach the top, the views are absolutely breathtaking and make the short trek well worth it. We also noticed a small café nearby, but we didn't stop in so can't comment on the food or service.

Overall, it's a great little stop if you're exploring the island – highly recommended if you've got an hour to spare and fancy a bita bit of history paired with stunning scenery.

places.generalDescription: Nestled at the pinnacle of the historic Street of the Knights, the Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes stands as a magnificent testament to medieval architecture and history. Originally constructed by the Knights Hospitaller in the early 14th century, this imposing fortress was built atop an earlier Byzantine stronghold from the 7th century. Once serving as both a grand residence and administrative hub for these valiant knights, it has witnessed centuries of change.

sources.snippet: The Palace of the Grand Master perched on top of Street of the Knights is a gigantic stronghold with a triple circuit of walls defending it sitting in Old Town’s highest point. This was erected on the location of the older Byzantine fortress (7th century AD) and was constructed by Knights Hospitaller or Knights of St. John (at the beginning of the 14th century), the Catholic military order that was the ruler of island from years 1309 to 1522. Situated on the square plan that centers on a massive internal courtyard, the building fell into bad shape after the knights departed.
sources.shortName: Rhodes Town - Travel Guide/Best Places to Visit in Rhodes

sources.snippet: Also known as the Kastello, the Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes is an impressive medieval castle at the highest point in Rhodes Town and one of the few examples of Gothic architecture in the whole of Greece. Previously a citadel of the Knights Hospitaller that functioned as a palace, headquarters and fortress, the palace is apparently built upon the foundations of an ancient temple of the Sun-god Helios. Today visitors can tour the castle and museum wit h an audio guide or visit one of the frequent exhibitions or performances that take place.
sources.shortName: The 12 Best Things to Do in Rhodes Town, Greece in 2025

sources.snippet: Also known as the Kastello, the headquarters of the Order of the Knights of St John is the stand-out building of the old town. The architecture alone is worth the visit and the spacious halls are filled with medieval decor, including Roman and Early Christian floor mosaics. On the ground floor is a permanent exhibition of artefacts dating from the early Christian era to the period of Ottoman rule.
sources.shortName: A tour of the medieval Old Town of Rhodes

sources.snippet: Often called the Kastello, the Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes is a castle at the highest point of the medieval city of Rhodes. The city of Rhodes is on the island of Rhodes in Greece. Originally built as a fortification, the Palace of the Grand Master played an important role in the defence of Rhodes throughout its history.
sources.shortName: Best Places To Visit In Rhodes' Medieval City

sources.snippet: The Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes, also called “Kastello”, is a castle inside the castle, in the old town of Rhodes. It was the administrative center of the Knights and the residence of each Master. Kastello’s current state owes to the Italian conquerors of Rhodes.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Castles of Rhodes

sources.snippet: The Palace of the Grand Master is located at the end of Knights Street. This is one of the best-preserved castles of the Mediterranean and the symbol of the island. It was constructed by the Knights of Saint John in Medieval times and was reconstructed in the early 20th century.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: The Palace of the Grand Master – it was originally a Byzantine fortress which later housed the administrative center of the Order of Knights. Nowadays the ground floor holds two large exhibits about the city of Rhodes.
sources.shortName: Wandering around the Old Town of Rhodes, Greece

sources.snippet: Walking through this imposing 14th-century structure with ancient art, architecture, exquisite marble, sculptures, and mosaics will give you a tiny glimpse of what life was like way back when.
sources.shortName: 11 Very Best Things To Do In Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Palace of the Grand Master of the Knights of Rhodes

reviews.text: Tickets are 20 EUR, but honestly, it's worth it, the palace is stunning, with beautifully preserved halls, mosaics and a real sense of history. The inner courtyard is impressive, and walking through the massive stone corridors feels like stepping back in time. Try to visit early in the day to avoid crowds and the heat. It's one of the must-see landmarks in Rhodes Old Town.

Plenty of fascinating history to explore, with what appears to be original decor or faithful reproductions. However, the €20 entry fee felt a bit steep for what was on offer and didn't quite deliver value for money. The experience could be improved with more interactive elements to better engage visitors. Still, it's worth a visit if you're a history buff or interested in medieval architecture.

This place is so neat!  Tickets are 20Euro or about $23 USD.  Get there as early as you can, it gets crowded fast.  Amazing restored rooms and furniture and so much to learn and see.  It is an impressive building and beautifully decorated.  There is a wonderful museum at the end to view as well.

places.generalDescription: Located above the village of Asklepios, the Castle of Asklipio was constructed by the Knights in the 15th century. Positioned at an altitude of approximately 250 meters, it offers breathtaking panoramic views. Although partially restored by the Italians in the early 20th century, much of it lies in ruins today. Accessible by foot or car, visitors can explore this small but intriguing site and enjoy stunning vistas of the surrounding landscape featuring sea, mountains, rocks, and trees.

sources.snippet: Passing the Knights’ Asklipio Castle, with sightlines to Faraklou, we reach the island’s southernmost cape. Here, at low tide, a double beach emerges, stretching like the neck of a Greek vase across to Prassonissi (meaning “green island”). We are tempted to swim again, but instead take a walk up a hill chequered with sandy-coloured remains of a 6th-century BC settlement.
sources.shortName: Rhodes: Castles, myths and sparkling azure bays

sources.snippet: To the east of the island, above the village of Asklepios, lies the homonymous Knight castle. It is at an altitude of about 250 meters, in a strategic post with stunning views. The Knights built the castle in the 15th century, initially the square tower and then the northwest corner tower.
sources.shortName: Top 5 Castles of Rhodes

sources.snippet: The Castle of Asklipio stands on a hill within a few minutes’ walk from Asklipio village, offering commanding views of the surrounding area. Though mostly ruined today, it was partly restored by the Italians in the early 20th century.
sources.shortName: Top 40+ Sights & Landmarks in Rhodes

sources.snippet: This is located on a hill 250 meters high in the Village Asklepio. Built in 15th century in 2 phases: the first fortified the square tower and the second tower in the northwest corner was repaired.
sources.shortName: Castles | Rhodes.gr

places.name: Castle of Asklipio

reviews.text:
This castle served as a base for the local administrator as well as for a refuge for the local populace during piratical raids.
The dense network of watchtowers would light the fires to provide the warning, and the people would rush to the castle as instructed. The Knights Hospitaler had detailed edicts with such instructions. In such an event, everyone knew where they should seek refuge.
Though heavily damaged, it retains its outline and its charm. It may be less exciting than other castles on Rhodes, but adventurous types will certainly find it interesting.
Easy to get to and free to visit, caution is required as the site is not maintained.  A nice cultural detour for those visiting the southern part of Rhodes.
Destroyed little castle. Nice place to go with a great overview until the sea. There are parking slots close to the castle. 100m away.

Really interesting castle ruins with commanding views over the countryside. Easily accessible with free parking in the village and a short walk up to the castle. This plus a visit to the museum & church plus a stop off in one of the cafes or tavernas and this makes a lovely morning or afternoon trip.

places.generalDescription: The Dodecanese Islands, situated in the southeastern Aegean near Turkey, offer a sunny escape with their crystal-clear waters and sandy or pebbly beaches. This group of twelve large islands and numerous smaller ones boasts significant archaeological sites, impressive Byzantine and medieval monuments, and unique traditional settlements. Unlike the more popular Cyclades, the Dodecanese Islands are known for their medieval architecture and tranquil beaches.

sources.snippet: Contact with the traditions of the Dodecanese changed the forms of Gothic architecture, and building after 1523 combined vernacular forms resulting from the meeting of two worlds with decorative elements of Ottoman origin. All the built-up elements dating before 1912 have become vulnerable because of the evolution in living conditions and they must be protected as much as the great religious, civil and military monuments, the churches, monasteries, mosques, baths, palaces, forts, gates and ramparts.
sources.shortName: Medieval Town of Rhodes - Greek Castles

sources.snippet: Rhodes, (which translates in “rose”) is a fairly big island, and it is the capital of Dodecanese, a complex of 12 islands. While, the island shows great beauty, across its whole area, it is the city of Rhodes that gets undoubtedly “the prize”.
sources.shortName: Things to do in Rhodes – Greece – Travelodium Travel Magazine

places.name: Dodecanese Islands

reviews.text:
The Dodecanese Islands
Played a significant role in history
Patmos is where John received the Revilation and wrote the last book of the Bible

Kos is where the father of doctors taught medicine and made his students the young Doctors take the Hypocatic oath

Rhodes was the Venitian island where they built a famous castle that was besieged by the Turks

I was fortunate to visit these beautiful  islands

Meat Heaven !!

Been coming to this place for a few years !

Always had the grills ... like half a cow on a plate with a ice scoop full of chips ....
Decide to go for salads this time around bit boring i know ... but it was not to disappoint .

Went for three salads ..... All perfectly Prepared to a high standard , tasty and fresh .
Aubergine salad was the only one that didn't really send taste buds  to the moon was bland and served in a small bowl ., Was all a it Mushy !!

Ate at the cooler counter watched the three grill chefs chopped and grill and plate boards in front of me ...
Had a black tea with Honey all magical and well priced ... would recommend ..

Kos island is a charmer - lush green and full of historical places. The traces of different rulers of the island can be seen to this very day!

If you plan to have your holidays there in the highest season (July - August) then choose the Northwest coast as you will  have a chance to cool down with the fresh breeze from the North and due to the colder waters of the Aegean Sea. If you'd rather go in September or October, then Kardamena is the place to go - protected from the Northern winds by the mountains it enjoys a longer season

The massive bastion of St. George depicts eloquently the transitional period of the adjustment of even the best medieval defensive networks to the needs of the age of gunpowder.
The initial tower is still visible and remains encased within the large overstructures that form a massive platform that can house a deadly assortment of cannons as well as men with all types of projectiles to be launched upon any enemy who would dare to approach.
It is strategically located upon the northwestern corner so as to defend the palace nearby as well as to forbid any attempt to attack the weaker walls of the waterfront by land.
Its defense was assigned to the Auberne branch, one of the most influential within the order of the Knights Hospitaler.

You can NOT walk up, there is a door, obviously closed and never to be opened. Nothing good in this direction. Nothing to see but trash and cars. Don't mistake it for entrances or the palace. This is an empty tower that isn't visitable.

Great to walk round the walls and see across the old city.  But more information would have been helpful.  At each of the locations there was a diagram and some explanation of what had been built when but without any connection between the two.  Which bit was the 'curtain wall'?  Things not identified which detracted from the experience.  But would still recommend the walk.  Why do the walls close at 3.00pm?  Doesn't seem necessary.

places.generalDescription: Feraklos Castle is a Byzantine-era stronghold of the Knights Hospitaller, perched on a hill overlooking the coast. It's one of the monumental archaeological sites in Rhodes, offering stunning views of the sea between Ayia Agathe and Charaki Bays. Visitors can explore this historical gem within walking distance from various accommodations and nearby attractions like Agathi Beach. The castle's strategic location provides a glimpse into the island's turbulent past, making it an essential stop for history enthusiasts.

sources.snippet: Castle built near the village of Malona on a hill 85 metres high overlooking the sea between the bays of Ayia Agathe and Charaki. It is also known as Faraklo or Charaki. Its remains date from the Byzantine and Hospitaller periods.
sources.shortName: Castles | Rhodes.gr

places.name: Feraklos Castle

reviews.text: Definitely worth the climb up. These ancient ruins are free to visit. The climb up is not too hard although Decent footwear is recommended because there a lot of loose rocks. The view a the top over the surrounding bay area is beautifull. There is ample parking space (free) at the bottom of the hill.

Really nice viewpoint with a mildly adventurous way up.

The dead goat was still there at the end of the tunnel, but other than that, perfect little trip
Great place to explore, not much left from castle

places.generalDescription: Gate d'Amboise is the innermost entrance to the Old Town, located near the palace. It's a remarkable 200-meter walk from the D'Amboise Gate. This historical site holds significance as Italian troops once entered Rhodes through this gate.

sources.snippet: Inside you can get through one of seven gates – St. Antonio’s Gate, Gate D’Amboise, St. Paul’s Gate, Arnauld Gate, Marine Gate, St. Mary’s Gate or St. Catherine’s Gate. In many travel guides, they recommend to start the tour from the Gate D’Amboise, and then take a walk along the Street of the Knights to the Palace of the Grand Masters.
sources.shortName: Wandering around the Old Town of Rhodes, Greece

places.name: Gate d'Amboise

reviews.text:
Grand Master Emery D' Amboise added this gate and reinforced it with two sturdy drum towers that housed cannons to bombard enemy forces approaching this critical position, so close to the palace, the very heart of the order.
The stone bridge seen today was a retractable wooden construct at that time (completed in 1512 as inscribed upon the gate).
Two more moats and two more gates must be overtaken before getting to the palace, which, of course, is a formidable fortress in itself. Furthermore, it is an architectural jewel.

Better arrive from this side, if you want to reach the entrance of the palace. The walk is setting the mood of the medieval atmosphere. The whole walk is for free and can be done even with kids. Near by many sellers and not too far from bars and if you're lucky parking spots.
Great piece of history, really amazing architecture. Always nice to see well preserved remains of what used to be one of the finest castles, as it is now.

places.generalDescription: The fortress Archangelos Fort is a great place to visit if you're interested in the city and nature around it. Parking can be a bit tricky, but the views from the top are definitely worth it.

sources.snippet: A stepped path leads up over “ceramic slopes”, the source of light clay still used to make sought-after local pottery, past herds of bleating goats, to Archangelos Castle. A ruined triangle of 15th-century fortification, it is an idyllic spot, home to a small modern chapel, scampering agama lizards and a delightful flutter of swallowtail butterflies, as well as panoramic sea views.
sources.shortName: Rhodes: Castles, myths and sparkling azure bays

sources.snippet: It is built on a rock 217 meters high, east of the Village of Archangelos and has an elliptic shape.
sources.shortName: Castles | Rhodes.gr

places.name: Archangelos Castle

reviews.text: Lovely walk through the village and not that much of a climb to the Castle. The views are spectacular and if you can time this in the evening, you will also get to see a spectacular sunset.

Nice Fort, few within Rhodes still conserved and free. It is possible to reach near there by car or have a moderate (depends on your physical condition) walk up hill. From there you will have a nice view of all of Archangels city and from the surrounding area.
Nice, old, castle up on the hill. Wear proper shoes and take something to drink with you. You can park car 200-300 meters away.
